title: Early experience with the vaginoscopic approach to outpatient microhysteroscopy.
abstract:
NoObjective To assess the outcome of the vaginoscopic approach to outpatient microhysteroscopy using a 2.5-mm semi-rigid hysteroscope without using a speculum, tenaculum or analgesia.\ud
Design \ud
A prospective observational study.\ud
Setting \ud
Outpatient hysteroscopy unit of a large district general hospital.\ud
Subjects \ud
24 women referred to the outpatient hysteroscopy unit with abnormal uterine bleeding.\ud
Results \ud
A total of 24 women had vaginoscopic outpatient microhysteroscopy. Of the procedures, 20 (83.4%) were successful using the technique and four (16.6%) failed procedures occurred. Pain was not encountered during the procedure.\ud
Conclusion \ud
Outpatient hysteroscopy with a semi-rigid 2.5-mm microhysteroscope using the vaginoscopic approach is a well-tolerated and successful technique for the evaluation of abnormal genital tract bleeding

Design \ud

Setting \ud
Outpatient hysteroscopy unit of a large district general hospital.\ud
Subjects \ud
24 women referred to the outpatient hysteroscopy unit with abnormal uterine bleeding.\ud
Results \ud
A total of 24 women had vaginoscopic outpatient microhysteroscopy. Of the procedures, 20 (83.4%) were successful using the technique and four (16.6%) failed procedures occurred. Pain was not encountered during the procedure.\ud
Conclusion \ud
Outpatient hysteroscopy with a semi-rigid 2.5-mm microhysteroscope using the vaginoscopic approach is a well-tolerated and successful technique for the evaluation of abnormal genital tract bleeding.</dc:description><dc:date>
